event.title: Forest Service personnel from left, Daubenmire, Boyd, Dedan, Foiles, Kardos, Chehok, Summerside, Rehfeldt, Kelhamek, Swanger, Steinhoff, Olson, Brown, Weistemer, Coffen, Carpenter, Deitschman (photographer)

data.event: Rexford Daubenmire, Botanist Washington State University, developed the system of habitat typing in the northern Rocky Mountains to predict site characteristics, site quality, and potential climax vegetation. He conducted training for Forest Service personnel in the identification of climax vegetation and use of habitat types for forest management. From left, Daubenmire, Boyd, Dedan, Foiles, Kardos, Chehok, Summerside, Rehfeldt, Kelhamek, Swanger, Steinhoff, Olson, Brown, Weistemer, Coffen, Carpenter, Deitschman (photographer)."

event.title: Strip cutting, Ames Creek

data.event: "Strip cutting, Ames Creek, DCEF. In this method of cutting the timber is clear-cut in strips extending up and down the hill and from 100 to 300 feet wide. Intervening strip of uncut or partially cut timber of somewhat lesser width are left for seeding purposes."

event.title: Experimental planting areas in western larch type (foreground) and western yellow pine type (hill in background).

data.event: Plate XVIII caption:"Experimental planting areas in western larch type (foreground) and western yellow pine type (hill in background). In immediate foreground experimental plot of western yellow pine transplants in study of climatic varieties." This plot remains at present and known as Plot 162, racial variation in ponderosa pine. White speck on the hill in background is the SW slope meteorological station.

event.title: Meteorological station on northwest [northeast?] slope representative of western white pine type.

data.event: Plate XVII caption:"Meteorological station on northwest [northeast?] slope representative of western white pine type. Slope covered with very dense growth of even aged douglas fir, western white pine and wstern larch with understory of western red cedar and western hemlock. One acre clearing made for the station site."

event.title: Western yellow pine stock fall 1912. T

data.event: Caption reads:"Fig. 7. View on west side Plot 22, lower south slope, planted to 1-1 western yellow pine stock fall 1912. The taller yellow pines and Douglas firs seen are not planted stock. The willows, etc. have increased copnsiderably in height growth and spread since 1912."

event.title: These plants have had much competition with pine grass.

data.event: Caption reads:"Fig. 9. Series B. Southwest slope. Plants No. 83, 84 and 85, Plot 22, spring 1922. These plants have had much competition with pine grass. They are not shaded or crowded by schrubs. Rather dry site."

event.title: Southwest slope with plants No. 20, 18, 2 and 19

data.event: Caption reads:"Fig. 10. Series B. Southwest slope. Plants No. 20, 18, 2 and 19, Plot 22, spring 1922. The plant in front of the board grows near an old trail. It has also considerable competition from grass and small shrubs. The plant to the right has had very little competition and no shade."

event.title: Western yellow pine planted in the spring of 1912.

data.event: Caption reads:"Fig. 5. Western yellow pine 1-0 stock, Helena seed, planted spring 1912

event.title: Southwest slope plant No. 44

data.event: Caption reads:"Fig. 11. Series B, southwest slope. Plant No. 44, Plot 22, spring 1921. This plant has been croweded by grass and shrubbery all its life, and has obtained very little light. The wonder is that it has hung on to life for 10 years. (Still alive fall 1922). Note the setback in height growth. It has evidently not been able to grow laterals."

event.title: Southwest slope plant No. 36

data.event: Caption reads:"Fig. 12. Series B, southwest slope. Plant No. 36, Plot 22, 1-1 western yellow pine, planted fall 1912. View spring 1922. A plant which has very little competition. It obtains full sunlight."

event.title: These are the only known photos of the interior of the original cottages

data.event: Scanned from the Larsen family album, on loan from Sue Marsh, great granddaughter of J.A. Larsen. These are the only known photos of the interior of the original cottages. Cottage 1 was the residence for the Larsen family 1917-21. J.A. Larsen started as a researcher and succeeded Donald Brewster as the second Station Director. Photo of master bedroom, cottage 1, no date, probably 1919-21 era. Note radiator.

event.title: View of Boulder Nursery, Helena National Forest, Montana.

data.event: D.S. Olson, first Nurseryman at Savenac Nursery, wrote in his brief history of Savenac, that the Boulder Nursery (to serve the Helena forest, along with one at Trapper Creek to serve the Bitterroot and another at Camp Crook to serve the Dakota National Forest), were established in 1908. These nurseries were maintained by a district ranger and known as ranger nurseries. Boulder and the other ranger nurseries were abandoned in 1916. Back of photo reads:"View of Boulder Nursery, Helena National Forest, Montana."

event.title: Deception Creek BRC Camp - 1952

data.event: As written on the back: :"Deception Creek BRC Camp - 1952". The Blister Rust Control project had been in progress for almost 30 years by 1952. Crews would comb the woods and grub out Ribes (genus of gooseberry and currant shrubs), the alternate host for white pine blister rust.

event.title: Overview of headquarters

data.event: Overview of headquarters; from a series of mounted photos of buildings and other features of DCEF, Moscow # 653-663. All photos filed in DCEF Box #1. Due to the remoteness of this site, the Research Station was unable to keep a full-time employee on the site; vandals and thieves took over and by about 1978, all buildings were removed.

event.title: General view of Ames Creek clear-cutting

data.event: "General view of Ames Creek clear-cutting with alternate western white pine shelterwood strips DCEF, Idaho. Cutting made in 1935. All merchantable meterial cut in clear-cut strips and the remainder felled and area broadcast burned in fall of 1936. In shelterwood strips about half the white pine volume was logged leaving about 20 M feet per acre. Trees of other species, mostly a hemlock understory, were removed in a stand improvement operation. Clear-cut strips are about 400 feet wide and shelterwood strips about 260 feet. Natural regeneration is expected. Taken 8-7-38."

event.title: Single and double burns in the Deep Creek and Jordan Creek area.

data.event: The following photos were used in a report by Larsen,"Study of Natural Regeneration After Fire, a Progress Report... Fall 1923". The report and photos are from single and double burns in the Deep Creek and Jordan Creek area northeast of the Magee Ranch. Caption reads:"Fig. 1. Looking west across Deep Creek toward Section 8 where two very severe fires (1910 and 1919) destroyed all living trees except some tall larches on the lower north aspect..."

event.title: Complete destruction by two hard burns in 1910 and 1919.

data.event: Caption reads:"Fig.3. Near view on middle north slope, Section 8, Deep Creek, showing complete destruction by two hard burns (1910 and 1919)..."

event.title: View across Deep Creek toward the southerly slopes in Section 8.

data.event: Caption reads:"View across Deep Creek toward the southerly slopes in Section 8..."

event.title: View of south aspect showing effect of double burn in Section 8.

data.event: Caption reads:"Fig.5. Near view of south aspect showing effect of double burn in Section 8, Deep Creek..."

event.title: Effect of the two fires (1910 and 1919) on north aspect of lower Jordan Creek canyon.

data.event: Caption reads:"Effect of the two fires (1910 and 1919) on north aspect of lower Jordan Creek canyon..."

event.title: View east up Jordan Creek.

data.event: Caption reads:"View east up Jordan Creek, Through the narrow canyon in foreground both the 1910 and the 1919 fires rushed to reach the upper basin..."

event.title: Complete work of two severe fires (1910 and 1919).

data.event: Caption reads:"Complete work of two severe fires (1910 and 1919). Lower canyon of Jordan Creek, Deep Creek area. Natural reproduction after four years, one seedling per acre."

data.event: Caption reads:"Fig.10. View north along Deep Creek from point between Deep Creek and Jordan Creek, Sec. 17..."

data.event: Caption reads:"Fig. 11. Steep lower south aspect on Jordan Creek, Section 16, burned bery hard in 1910 and 1919. Natural reproduction nil..."

event.title: Weather instruments

data.event: The following Fire Album images came from a scrapbook produced by the the Northern Rocky Mountain Forest and Range Exp. Sta. (Gisborne, Jemison, and Hayes probably had a big part in it) describing the use of weather instruments and evaluating the fire danger. Photos are by K.D. Swan unless otherwise noted.

event.title: The main weather station where daily measurements have been made since 1912.

data.event: "The main weather station where daily measurements have been made since 1912. A summary of these records for 1912 to 1931, inclusive, is available upon request."

event.title: The main weather station in the foreground is supplemented by instruments mounted in the tree top.

data.event: "The main weather station in the foreground is supplemented by instruments mounted in the tree top 135 feet above the ground. More recently these tree top instruments have been moved to the top of the 150-foot steel tower in the background."

event.title: Northern Rocky Mountain Wind Gage, mounted on a fence post

data.event: "A Northern Rocky Mountain Wind Gage, mounted on a fence post, The number of revolutions per minute indicates the wind velocity more accurately than it can be estimated. This device costs less than $3."

event.title: Instruments to indicate humidity and temperature

data.event: "Two inexpensive idicators of relative humidity. The one at the right also indicates air temperature."

event.title: Joy Armstrong with the Hazen instrument shelter.

data.event: "Testing several low-priced humidty indicators. These were not found satisfactory for out-of-door use. Note this special type of instrument shelter. There are several other types less expensive than this." This is a Hazen instrument shelter and still in use at PREF. Pictured is Joy Armstrong.

event.title: DCEF headquarters site development.

data.event: DCEF headquarters site development.

event.title: View across area slashed for burning to prevent fire hazard on Priest River Exp. For. July-Augst 1932.

data.event: Found at PREF, these mounted photos have been stored in box marked"PREF Photo Boxs 1 or 1A" and now reside in the Moscow FSL. "View across area slashed for burning to prevent fire hazard on Priest River Exp. For. July-Augst 1932."

event.title: Large dowel tested at an inflammability station for reliability in measuring fuel moisture.

data.event: Large dowel tested at an inflammability station for reliability in measuring fuel moisture. The following two photos show a variety of diameters being tested

event.title: The quadruple register which records rain, wind, direction, and sunshine. This instrument is now in the PREF museum.

data.event: "The quadruple register which records (1) every 1/100th inch of rain, (2) every mile of wind, (3) the direction from which the wind is blowing, and (4) every minute of sunshine." This instrument is now in the PREF museum.

event.title: Service gages used each summer in Region One.

data.event: "A comparison of raingages. The Forest Service gagem in which a measurement is being made, costs $1.50. The U.S. Weather Bureau standard 8-inch gage, costing from $9 to $11 is at the left. The large gage, at the right is electrically recording and costs about $100, without the recorder. About 400 of the Forest Service gages are used each summer in Region One." Pictured is G. Lloyd Hayes.

event.title: Three types of duff hygrometers

data.event: "Three types of duff hygrometers, for measuring the moisture content, hence inflammability, of dead leaves, twigs, etc., covering the forest floor. There was no instrument for this purpose before fire research and the Forest Products produced this device. The pencil points to a piece of rattan which is the actuating element."

event.title: Device for measuring wood moisture.

data.event: "Another device for measuring wood moisture. This Blinkometer invented by M.E. Dunlap of the Forest Products Laboratory for studying the moisture content of lumber is being found very useful in forest fire research. It is only during extremely critical years that logs of this size dry out sufficiently in the center so that they burn completely." Pictured is George Jemison.

event.title: Four types of psychrometers for measuring the relative humidty of the atmosphere.

data.event: "Four types of psychrometers for measuring the relative humidty of the atmosphere. Each type has its particular advantages and special uses. There are at least three other types, also used."

event.title: Headquarters construction

data.event: Headquarters construction progress at the end of the 1934 season.

event.title: The interior of a meteorologcal instrument shelter.

data.event: "The interior of a meteorologcal instrument shelter. Included here are maximum and minimum thermometers, a hygrothermograph, and the Weather Bureau type of whirling psychrometer."

event.title: An ordinary maximum thermometer is used to check the accuracy of the automatic recorder.

data.event: "An ordinary maximum thermometer is inserted in the duff and used to check the accuracy of the automatic recorder. The vertical wire pin is used to prevent pack rats from stealing the thermometer. The sling psychrometer handle is used to facilitate 'setting' the thermometer."

event.title: A barograph and a mercurial barometer for measuring the weight or pressure of the atmosphere.

data.event: "A barograph and a mercurial barometer for measuring the weight or pressure of the atmosphere. Such measurements are essential to accurate weather forecasting. Aneroid baromenters may also be used, if they are checked for accuracy by comparison with mercurial barometer measurements."

event.title: Wood cylinders

data.event: "So that the wood cylinders used at all stations may be exactly alike they are lathe-turned from carefully selected ponderosa pine sapwood. Two sizes are used, the 1/2-inch diameter 'triplets', and the 2-inch diameter size. Both are 18 inches long. At all stations the cylinders are held level, 10 inches above the ground, with the ends pointing north and south, the tagged end north, and the number right side up." G. Lloyd Hayes

event.title: Large dowel tested at an inflammability station for reliability in measuring fuel moisture.

data.event: Large dowel tested at an inflammability station for reliability in measuring fuel moisture. The following two photos show a variety of diameters being tested

event.title: Weighing a set of triplets to determine their moisture content.

data.event: "Weighing a set of triplets to determine their moisture content. Moisture contents can be determined to an accuracy of 1%. Moistures of less than 5% are extremely critical. The air temperature must be 100? F. or more and the relative humidity must be 10% or less for many hours in order to produce 2% moisture in the half-inch cylinders." G. Lloyd Hayes.

event.title: Duff hygrometer spikes being dried in an electric oven.

data.event: "Every duff hygrometer must be calibrated annually. This is done by testing each instrument in several cans each filled with duff of known moisture content. These cans, with holes in the ends for inserting the duff hygrometer spikes, are shown here being dried in an electric oven." G. Lloyd Hayes; the oven is still in use.

event.title: Duff hygrometer properly inserted in the duff.

data.event: "One duff hygrometer properly inserted in the duff, with the spike horizontal and covered by only a thin layer of duff. The instrument on top the duff indicated the length of the spike, and shows the dial face opened for reading."

event.title: Set of weed cylinders and a duff hygrometer properly set beneath a standard screen.

data.event: "Measurement of duff and wood moisture at many stations must be made under the same amount of shade if they are to be accurately comparable. A wire screen is provided to all stations so that this shade may be the same at all of them. This photo shows a set of weed cylinders and a duff hygrometer properly set beneath a standard screen."

event.title: Measuring relative humidity by use of a 'pocket type' sling psychrometer.

data.event: "Measuring relative humidity by use of a 'pocket type' sling psychrometer. Such measurements are always made in the shade, protected from direct sun, and protected from rain, but in freely circulating air." G. Lloyd Hayes.

event.title: Continuous records of temperature and humidity are obtained by use of either a hygrothermograph (top) or a hygrograph (left) and a thermograph (right).

data.event: "Continuous records of temperature and humidity are obtained by use of either a hygrothermograph (top) or a hygrograph (left) and a thermograph (right). Human hair is used as the active element in the hygrograph shown."

event.title: An inexpensive ($8) instrument shelter.

data.event: "An inexpensive ($8) instrument shelter. Exposed inside of it are: maximum and minimum thermometers, soil and air temperature recorder, and a hygrograph for recording relative humidity." Joy Armstrong.

event.title: One type of soil and air temperature recorder.

data.event: "One type of soil and air temperature recorder. The long bulb in the foreground is inserted forizontally in the sod or duff at the depth desired. The special coil on the left side of the instrument responds to air temperature. A surface duff temperature of 148�? has been recorded at Priest River with this instrument. On that day, the maximum thermometer, shown on the next page, registered an absolute maximum of 158?F. The maximum temperature of the air was 105? that day."

event.title: The interior of a meteorologcal instrument shelter.

data.event: "The interior of a meteorologcal instrument shelter. Included here are maximum and minimum thermometers, a hygrothermograph, and the Weather Bureau type of whirling psychrometer."

event.title: Anemometer to determine wind velocity.

data.event: "Reading the anemometer to determine wind velocity 8 feet above the ground. A second anemometer mounted in the tree top 135 feet above the ground records the wind velocity automatically. The wind in the tree top is usually about three times that at the 8-foot level." G. Lloyd Hayes

event.title: Large dowel tested at an inflammability station for reliability in measuring fuel moisture.

data.event: Large dowel tested at an inflammability station for reliability in measuring fuel moisture. The following two photos show a variety of diameters being tested

event.title: 3-cup anemomete

data.event: "A 3-cup anemometer which (1) registers mileage on its dial in the manner of the mileage dial on an automobile, (2) registers every mile of wind when connected to a suitable recorder, and (3) registers the current velocity when properly connected to an electrical buzzer. Such an instrument costs about $80."

event.title: A 'single magnet register' for recording wind velocity.

data.event: A 'single magnet register' for recording wind velocity only. A 3-cup or 4-cup anemometer is used with this register. The two 'wet cells' supply the electric current for actuating the magnet.

event.title: Same as Moscow #653

data.event: Same as Moscow #653

event.title: A 'two magnet register' for recording wind velocity, rainfall, and sushine.

data.event: "A 'two magnet register' for recording wind velocity, rainfall, and sushine. This instrument was used for 23 summers ar the Priest River station. It was recently replaced by the quadrruple register shown below."

event.title: The measurements of the several factors of fire danger.

data.event: Section title: "The measurements of the several factors of fire danger illustrated in the foregoing pictures..."

event.title: The Forest Rangers keep accurate comparable records of the important factors of fire danger.

data.event: "The Forest Rangers keep accurate comparable records of the important factors of fire danger. The records of wind duff or wood moisture and the class of danger are plotted daily on a standard chart form. At Priest River additional records of fuel moisture reveal differences in inflammability in the full sun under half shade and under the full shade of a dense timber canopy." J.B. Thompson.

event.title: Panoramic view of the HQ site in Moscow

data.event: 3 photos taken to create the panoramic view of the HQ site in Moscow #'s 676 and 677.

event.title: Two-way voice radio is used to broadcast fire danger measurements to field stations and to report to the Regional office.

data.event: "The Forest Service, two-way voice radio is used to broadcast fire danger measurements to field stations and to report to the Regional office. As these reports are based on similar measurements at all stations they are fully comparable. This ranger is reporting Class 3 danger, resulting from a 7-mile wind, visibility over 8 miles, minimum humidity 21%, and a fuel moisture of 12%." J.B. Thompson.

event.title: The device illustrates the most important factors of fire danger into a rating on a scale of 1 to 7.

data.event: "The device illustrated here, and shown in the ranger's hands on the last photograph, integrates the several most important factors of fire danger into a rating on a scale of 1 to 7. As illustrated here, the meter shows Class 4 danger for any day between June 16 and July 10 if there has been no recent lightning, if visibility is 8 miles, fuel moisture 5% to 7%, wind 8 to 12 m.p.h., and humidity above 15%."

event.title: Chart illustrates the type of record kept by the forest ranger and supervisors.

data.event: "This chart illustrates the type of record kept by the forest ranger and supervisors. The fire control action needed to meet each of the seven classes of fire danger is described on the Fire Danger Meter, previously illustrated."

data.event: "Clear cut station, February 23, 1932."

event.title: Differences in air temperature and humidity caused by different amounts of shade.

data.event: "Differences in air temperature and humidity caused by different amounts of shade."

event.title: Label introducing the paired altitude/aspect stations.

data.event: Label introducing the next section which discusses the paired altitude/aspect stations.

event.title: The north slope station at 2700 feet elevation.

data.event: "The north slope station at 2700 feet elevation." G. Lloyd Hayes

event.title: Differences in factors of fire danger resulting from differences in density of the forest.

data.event: "Striking differences in other factors of fire danger resulting from differences in density of the forest. These data show that when an area is partially cutover the shade of the residual stand has a very beneficial effect in reducing fire danger. Careless brush burning destroys this shade and thereby increases future fire danger."

event.title: The south slope station at 2700 feet elevation.

data.event: "The south slope station at 2700 feet elevation." do.

event.title: The north slope station at 3800 feet elevation.

data.event: "The north slope station at 3800 feet elevation. The poles bracing the fence on the uphill side are to break the pressure of the deep snow settling down the slope during the winter time."

event.title: The south slope station at 3800 feet elevation.

data.event: "The south slope station at 3800 feet elevation." G. Lloyd Hayes

event.title: The north slope station at 5500 feet elevation.

data.event: "The north slope station at 5500 feet elevation." George M. Jemison

event.title: The south slope station at 5500 feet elevation.

data.event: "The south slope station at 5500 feet elevation." do.

event.title: Weather station in midwinter

data.event: "Same view of weather station in midwinter, Feb. 1932."

event.title: The Clear-Cut or Full Sun station at Priest River.

data.event: "The Clear-Cut or Full Sun station at Priest River. All meteorological and fire danger factors are measured here twice each day from early May to late September." G.L. Hayes

event.title: Label introducing the inflammability stations.

data.event: Label introducing the next section which discusses the inflammability stations.

event.title: The Half-Cut of Half Shade station at Priest River.

data.event: "The Half-Cut of Half Shade station at Priest River. Fuels are not so dry here, as in the full sun; the shade of the trees left after logging causing lower temperature, higher humidity, and less wind." G.L. Hayes

event.title: The Full Timbered or Full Shade station at Priest River.

data.event: "The Full Timbered or Full Shade station at Priest River. Although the volume of fuels is greater here than at the Clear Cut or Half Cut stations, the higher moisture contenets under dense shade produce lower inflammability and easier fire control under ordinary conditions." G.M. Jemison

event.title: fuel bygrograph

data.event: "A relatively new product of fire research called a fuel bygrograph. This instrument produces continuous record of (1) wood moisture, (2) duff moisture, and (3) wind velocity. The unique design ws originated by the U.S. Forest Products Laboratory. An electric buzzer shakes the instrument gently once each hour to eliminate any inaccuracy due to the drag of the pens on the paper." G.M. Jemison

event.title: The anemometer is mounted on the standard at the man's left.

data.event: "The man's right hand points to the six wood cylinders; his left points to the duff hygrograph spike, covered with duff. The anemometer is mounted on the standard at the man's left." H.T. Gisborne

event.title: Reading the anemometer dial, as a check on the wind record shown by the instrument.

data.event: "Reading the anemometer dial, as a check on the wind record shown by the instrument. The wood cylinders are weighed periodically to check the accuracy of their chart record. Standard duff hygrometers are used to check the chart record of duff moisture." H.T. Gisborne

event.title: Wood cylinders used for indicating the moisture content.

data.event: "Wood cylinders are used for indicating the moisture content, hence inflammability, of small dead branchwood. This photograph shows a comparison being made of natural versus manufacturred half-inch diameter sticks. The lack of uniformity of natural sticks is clearly evident."

event.title: Top photo: Fire runs up these dead trees and jumps from snag to snag. Bottom photo:Close up view of the fuels on the ground beneath the snags and reproduction shown above.

data.event: Top photo:"A dangerous fuel type. Fire runs up these dead trees and jumps from snag to snag." Bottom photo:"Close up view of the fuels on the ground beneath the snags and reproduction shown above." Caption:"When the dead twigs, branchwood, and duff on the ground become dry and inflammable men must arrive quickly if fires are to be controlled while still small. Measurements of the dryness of these fuels are more dependable than meteorological data for indicating the degree of inflammability."

event.title: Unmerchantable and decayed material left after logging original stand of western white pine.

data.event: "Unmerchantable and decayed material left after logging original stand of western white pine. On this area, all hemlock and white fir were cut down after logging and the area burned broadcast. A single burn. This tract later burned over the second time and prevented satisfactory restocking. After waiting ten years for reproduction, the area was planted. Jergens [sic] Flat, Kaniksu National Forest."

event.title: Margaret and Jennie in 7-passenger Studebaker.

data.event: Caption titled"Margaret and Jennie in 7-passenger Studebaker. (Note Jennie's feather hat) This is the car that lost the front wheel when we drove to Coolin to escape the forest fire." The fire was probably the Highlanding fire of 1922; there was mention of the fire, the drive to Coolin, and losing the front wheel of the car in the recollections of Margaret's experience at PRES. Her account has been scanned and filed in the PREF archive, under the subdirectory General.

event.title: This picture shows the rather open overwood remaining and the slash piles ready to be burned.

data.event: "Barney Creek, Coeur d'Alene NF. Mature, 200-yr. mixed white pine stand cutover by the Ohio Match Co. in 1932. Following logging most of the hemlock and white fir was felled and the slash piled on top of the white pine slash resulting from the logging. This picture shows the rather open overwood remaining and the slash piles ready to be burned. Taken 11/."/

event.title: General view of hemlock disposal work, Tom Lavin Creek. Area logged by Ohio Match Co. in 1934 for white pine only.

data.event: "General view of hemlock disposal work, Tom Lavin Creek. Area logged by Ohio Match Co. in 1934 for white pine only. Most of the hemlock and white fir, which is unmerchantable in this area, has been felled and the slash piled on top of the white pine slash resulting from logging. Logging railroad, landing, and chute in the foreground. Taken 9/20/35."

event.title: Party with Pinchot and Graves, Deception Creek Expt. Forest, Aug 5, 1937.

data.event: From the photo record:"Party with Pinchot and Graves, Deception Creek Expt. Forest, Aug 5, 1937. Left to right the party includes: Howard Drake (Logging Engineer, CDA NF); Gifford Pinchot; Meyer H. Wolff (Ass't. Regional Forester, Recreation and Lands, R1); Herbert A. Smith; Evan Kelley (regional Forester R1); Kenneth P. Davis (Chief, Div. of Silviculture, Northern Rocky Mtn, Expt. Station); Baron Gisbert von Romberg (visiting German forester); Stephen N. Wyckoff (Dir., Northern Rocky Mtn, Expt. Station); Charles D. Simpson (Supervisor, CDA NF); Virgil Moody (Timber Sales, CDA NF); James E. Ryan (Supervisor, Kaniksu NF); William W. Larsen (Ranger, CDA NF); Elers Koch (Asst. Regional Forester, Timber Management, R1); William Guernsey (Asst. Forest Supervisor, CDA NF); George Haynes (Staff Asst. CDA NF); Bill Rinkle (Pinchot's chauffer); and Henry Solon Graves (Chief)."

event.title: Yellow (ponderosa) pine planting site looking south.

data.event: From Larsen's progress report of the status of the yellow (ponderosa) pine source of seed study, installed in 1911 on what is now part of the Benton nursery at the Priest River EF. Interesting as a historical background of the project and photos of the site in 1911, 1915, and 1917. The site still exists and is now known as plot 162, the ponderosa pine racial variation plot. The site is now the Benton nursery, still in use today. This photo shows the planting site, looking south. Caption reads:"Plate I, Benton Flat Looking South, 1911. Before removing the scattered small trees and brush previous to planting."

event.title: Averill,Hatch,Munns,Marshall,Gisborne,Koch,Weidman,Larsen August 1927.

data.event: "Averill,Hatch,Munns,Marshall,Gisborne,Koch,Weidman,Larsen August 1927." Averill and Hatch were PREF field assistants 1926-27; Munns was Chief, Division of Forest Influences; Marshall was at PREF 1925-28; Gisborne and fire research 1922-49; Koch was District (Region) 1 Timber Management; Weidman was Director of NRMFRES 1922-31; Larsen arrived at PREF 1913; bcame Station Director 1917-22.

event.title: Portion of area in Upper Sands Creek timber sale

data.event: "Portion of area in Upper Sands Creek timber sale. This area was logged in 1916, leaving all western white pine trees below 14 inches in diameter and from 4 to 6 seed trees above 14 inches in diamater. The hemlock and white fir were girdled at that time. The area has reproduced well; the present logging has removed the white pine trees reserved 20 years ago. 8/26." [8/36]

event.title: Disposal of undesirable hemlock by felling and piling for burning.

data.event: D-100"Disposal of undesirable hemlock by felling and piling for burning. D-99 As an alternate method, hemlock 10 inches and over was girdled and trees less than 10 inches felled and the slash burned. View shows the girdling and the stump of a smaller tree cut. The purpose of both methods is to remove undesirable species and to open up the stand sufficiently to permit the establishment of white pine reproduction. When the area is sufficiently well stocked, the area will be clearcut of pine."

event.title: Disposal of overdense hemlock reproduction from under a 140-year-old shelterwood of western white pine.

data.event: "Disposal of overdense hemlock reproduction from under a 140-year-old shelterwood of western white pine, Sands Creek, DCEF, Idaho. About 65 or 70 years ago a light ground fire evidently went through this particular area killing only a portion of the stand. The stand was opened up sufficiently, however, to let in natural reproduction in great abundance. Although western white pine seedlings also became established, the shelterwood was too dense to permit their subsequent development and they were choked out by the more tolerant hemlock reproduction. The resultant tangle of stagnated hemlock-literally dog-hair thick-was given up as hopeless and is as shown in this view being cut out to try to get new reproduction of pine. This is an example of what can happen in partial cuttings in the western white pine type if the shelterwood is not removed in time. Taken 8-6-38."

event.title: Rain gage near office. Gisborne with dipstick.

data.event: "Rain gage near office. Gisborne with dipstick. The inexpensive, forest service designed, rain gage has been tested for 3 years at PR in comparison with more expenseive, standard rain gagues and has been found to be of sufficient accuracy for fire control use. With 450 of these gages in use in Region One, a savings of more than $3000 has been effected by use of the cheaper gage."

event.title: Areas suitable for experimental investigations in western yellow pine.

event.title: Meteorological station on southwest slope, Priest River Experimental Station

data.event: Plate XVI caption:"Meteorological station on southwest slope, Priest River Experimental Station. Notice presence of yellow pine seedlings in the foreground and tall spires of fire-killed larch and the dense stand of young larch on the bench beyond; on northerly slope in the background well stocked stand of white pine, Douglas fir and larch. These three sites represent the three most important types of the region, the dry yellow pine and Douglas fir type of the southest slopes, the intermediate larch type of the more or less dry bench land, and the white pine type of the moist northerly slopes.
